newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP rises, dealers say turning around.
newsitem.headline: SAP rises, dealers say turning around.

text.p: Shares in German business software manufacturer SAP AG rose ahead of the market on Tuesday, with dealers saying the stock had found its floor, after a dramatic fall in the last fortnight.

SAP preference shares, listed on the DAX index of 30 leading shares, rose four marks, or almost two percent, to 195.80 marks by 1124 GMT. The stock had ended Monday's trade at its lowest level since April.
Meanwhile, the DAX was up 0.48 percent, or 12.71 points, at 2,684.57 points.
Two weeks ago SAP preference shares lost almost a quarter of their value in one day after the firm issued a profit warning.
Bayerische Vereinsbank AG said it was keeping SAP on its buy list and dealers at other banks also said SAP was being recommended.
Bayerische Vereinsbank said it had issued four option notes on SAP preference shares, three calls with a strike prices of 220, 230 and 240 marks and a put option with a 210 mark strike price.
The options will run from November 12 until March 19.
"The outlook for the software maker is still favourable," said Vereinsbank. "The average profit growth rate is estimated at 30 percent until 1998."
Vereinsbank said it expected a mid-term SAP share price of 240 marks.
